title: Component title
body:
Value: The value related to a specific attribute.

Categorical data: A limited list of specified values.

Ordinal data: Values with a meaningful order.

Continuous data: Values within a certain range.

Schema: A definition of the attributes, values and value types in a dataset.

Metadata: Data about data.

Tabular data: Data organised in rows and columns.

Hierarchical data: Data organised in a tree like structure.

Network data: Data where relationships and bi-directional or cyclic.

File format: A standard method to encode data for digital storage.

Fitness for purpose: How suitable a dataset is to answer a particular question or deliver a particular insight.

_graphic.attribution: Ella's Dad [CC-BY]
Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Schemas
body:
It might not always be clear what classes of data are present in a dataset (i.e. Is there an ordinal scale or not?). This is where a schema can help. 

The collection of attributes used in a particular dataset, and the way they are organised, is called a ‘schema’.

Schemas can be as simple as defining which column names to use in a spreadsheet, and what should go into them (e.g. numbers, date/time information, text descriptions, etc).

title: Characteristics of datasets
body:
The characteristics of a dataset influence what you can do with it and how valuable it is for your project.

There are a number of key dataset characteristics to consider, e.g. 

  • structure 
  • file formats used
  • size 
  • terms of use (covered in "Data usage rights" earlier)
  • fitness for a particular purpose

These and other characteristics influence how data may be used.

title: Data types
body:
Broadly speaking, data can be numbers, facts, collections of words, pictures, or any other value that has been captured or recorded in some way. 

Data can be quantitative (i.e. numerical values) or qualitative (i.e. descriptive).

  • “Rainfall yesterday: 5mm” is an example of quantitative data.
  • “Today will be cloudy with sunny periods” is an example of qualitative data.

Data can be:

  • Digital (i.e. an Excel spreadsheet)
  • Non-digital (i.e. a collection of scribbled notes)

title: Basic classes of data
body:
Data attributes will vary a lot across our different areas of business. Therefore, it is very important when collecting or acquiring data to define the attributes and acceptable set of values related to those. 

The values of a data attribute typically fall into one of the following classes:

  • Categorical data can only take certain values, e.g. Arup Regions
  • Ordinal data has a meaningful order or sequence, e.g. Arup Grades
  • Continuous data can take any value within a certain range, e.g. Years of service

The class that your data falls into will influence the type of analysis that can be conducted on the data.

In statistics, these classes are referred to as ‘Levels of Measurement’. There are more of them, but the principles remain the same.

title: Examining the characteristics of a data
displayTitle: Examining the characteristics of a data
body: A data record (shown below) is typically made up of many parts. At the heart of of data record are attributes and values. These values can have many types (e.g. categorical, ordinal and continuous) and these influence the analysis that can be performed. Tightly controlling the types helps ensure consistency and quality of the data. The attributes and value types are defined by a schema. It is much easier to integrate data if multiple parties use the same schema. Finally, comprehensive metadata (data about data) is a key element of effective data governance as it will often define our rights to use and share the data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Data usage rights
body: It is of critical importance to consider our rights and responsibilities when using and sharing both our own and third party data. Data exists on a spectrum. Explore the spectrum below and see if you can identify datasets that exist in each area.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Test your knowledge
body: Which of the following are examples of tabular, hierarchical and network data?

title: Assessing data requirements
body: Once you have determined which are your rights and requirements of using data, you will next have to assess if the data requirements meet your project needs. In the following sections you will explore what those requirements are to help you identify if the data is right for your purposes.

title: Test your knowledge
body: Are the following datasets examples of open, shared or closed data?

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

An increasing amount of open data, including transport timetables, has led to an explosion in the development of applications that integrate such data, helping people get from one place to another. Open data is freely available without having to negotiate complex licence terms, this reduces the friction to collecting and using the data. 

Not all data is open. Personal records of employees of ARUP contain not only personal, but confidential information and should remain closed. 

Just because you can find data on the web, doesn't mean it is open to be used. You should carefully check the terms of use and/or licence related to that data before doing anything with it.

title: Summary
body:
From managing the company to running and delivering projects, data can play a key role in informing us on the best decisions to make.

To get the most from data it is necessary to assess if data can help us solve the problem. This starts with evaluating our rights and legal obligations associated with the data in question. Following this, we need to set requirements that ensure the data is fit for purpose. From the attributes, data types and schema to structure, file format and size, all these requirements are important to specify carefully at the start of any project using data.

title: Essential terminology
body:
Data: Quantities, characters or symbols etc on which analysis can be performed.

Dataset: A collection of data that is treated as a single unit (e.g collection of records).

Degree of structure: How structured or unstructured the data is.

Structured data: Any data stored in a consistent, fixed format. 

Semi-structured data: Organised by does not obey a formal fixed structure.

Unstructured data: Not organised in any pre-defined manner.

Degree of openness: Is the data open, shared or closed.

Terms of use: State what we are allowed to do with the data.

Attribute: The name for a specific property of feature of a data record.

title: Decoding a dataset
body:
A data record (shown here) is typically made up of many parts. It is important to understand what each of the parts are and why they are important. In this section we are going to explore:

  • Attributes & Values
  • Metadata
  • Data types
  • Data structures

_graphic.attribution: Ella's Dad [CC-BY]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Decoding data formats
body:
There are many types structured data. These different structures are defined by the relationship between the attributes in a record or the relationship between records in a dataset. 

Broadly speaking there are three types of data structure, tabular, hierarchical and network that are each suited to different data formats.

_items.title: Tabular data
_items.body:
The most common structure for data is tabular. Data is organised into rows, each containing a single record. 

Formats like XLS, CSV and databases like Postgres, MySQL and Oracle are ideally suited for tabular data.

_graphic.attribution: Benjaminec [Shutterstock standard licence]

_items.title: Hierarchical data
_items.body:
Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data records, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country.

Formats such as XML and JSON and semi-structured databases (e.g. NoSQL) are more suited for hierarchical data.

In some cases hierarchical data structures can also be use to embed nested data in a record, e.g.

Company name: ARUP
Company location: {
    lat: 51.5216039
    long: -0.1377894
}

Nested data can also be created using multiple tables in a relational database.

_graphic.attribution: Ing Andrej Kaprinay [Shutterstock standard licence]

_items.title: Network data
_items.body:
Network data allows relationships to exist between any combination of records in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure is a social network. Consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn or your network of friends on Facebook.

The Web is another example of a network data structure, where webpages link to any number of other pages in any direction.

Network data can be represented in JSON-LD and XML/RDF. Both of these formats follow the Resource Description Framework (RDF) try to simplify and standardise the way network data is represented.

_graphic.attribution: Ovchinnkov Vladimir [Shutterstock standard licence]

title: Essential terminology
body:
Data: Quantities, characters or symbols etc on which analysis can be performed.

Dataset: A collection of data that is treated as a single unit (e.g collection of records).

Degree of structure: How structured or unstructured the data is.

Structured data: Any data stored in a consistent, fixed format. 

Semi-structured data: Organised by does not obey a formal fixed structure.

Unstructured data: Not organised in any pre-defined manner.

Degree of openness: Is the data open, shared or closed.

Terms of use: State what we are allowed to do with the data.

Attribute: The name for a specific property of feature of a data record.

title: Component title
body:
Value: The value related to a specific attribute.

Categorical data: A limited list of specified values.

Ordinal data: Values with a meaningful order.

Continuous data: Values within a certain range.

Schema: A definition of the attributes, values and value types in a dataset.

Metadata: Data about data.

Tabular data: Data organised in rows and columns.

Hierarchical data: Data organised in a tree like structure.

Network data: Data where relationships and bi-directional or cyclic.

File format: A standard method to encode data for digital storage.

Fitness for purpose: How suitable a dataset is to answer a particular question or deliver a particular insight.

_items.title: Structured data
_items.body:
Structured data refers to any data stored in a consistent, fixed format. 

Think of data in relational databases or high quality spreadsheets.

Well structured data is often referred to as machine readable; in a form that a computer can process without human assistance. 

Did you know? A "Total" row to the bottom of a spreadsheet will break machine readability and the consistent structure. Tip: Put data analysis in a separate sheet to the data!

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

_items.title: Semi-structured data
_items.body:
Semi-structured data does not obey a formal fixed structure. 

Semi-structured data can be:

1. A mix of structured and unstructured data

2. Self-describing using a range of attributes or tags that are not fixed.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

_items.title: Unstructured data
_items.body:
Unstructured data is not organised in any pre-defined manner. The majority of text based, such as free text responses to surveys, is unstructured.

Typically unstructured data cannot be easily analysed and requires some level of human interpretation, preprocessing or coding.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

title: The data lifecycle
body:
The data life cycle is the sequence of stages that a particular dataset goes through from its initial generation or capture to its eventual archival and/or deletion. 

The individual life cycle for each dataset will often be controlled by our legal objections; either defined by the terms of use or as embodied in law.  

Such obligations will often dictate:

  • What we can use the dataset for
  • How long we can retain it
  • Who we can share it with
  • Where the data can be stored

title: Data requirements
body:
Data is the fundamental building block from which knowledge is derived. To get the most from data it is necessary to understand the different forms it can take and its application throughout the complete data lifecycle. In this module we are going to explore:

  • What is data?
  • Structured, semi-structured and unstructured data
  • Open, shared and closed data
  • The characteristics of data
  • Data formats
  • Establishing the fitness for purpose of a dataset
  • The data lifecycle

title: Component title
body: Categorise the following into Qualitative and Quantitative data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Data can originate from many sources and be captured in many ways.

Data often becomes useful only once it is queried or analysed in some way, e.g.:

  • What was the average daily rainfall in my home town last month?
  • How many people in my team prefer noodles to pizza?

Quantitative data, including sensor readings, timesheet and the majority of that collected through surveys provides structured, numeric, objective and easy to interpret results. 

Qualitative data, including interview notes, reports and photos are more subjective. While being harder to analyse with automated methods, qualitative data provides deeper insight into underlying reasons, opinions and motivations.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data can originate from many sources and be captured in many ways.

Data often becomes useful only once it is queried or analysed in some way, e.g.:

  • What was the average daily rainfall in my home town last month?
  • How many people in my team prefer noodles to pizza?

Quantitative data, including sensor readings, timesheet and the majority of that collected through surveys provides structured, numeric, objective and easy to interpret results. 

Qualitative data, including interview notes, reports and photos are more subjective. While being harder to analyse with automated methods, qualitative data provides deeper insight into underlying reasons, opinions and motivations.

title: Attributes, values and metadata
body:
At the heart of a data record are attributes and values. An attribute is the name for a specific property or feature of a thing. Sometimes they are also referred to as properties, elements or fields.

Each attribute will have an associated value (i.e. latitude/longitude, postal code, or description).

In order for a data record to be usable, comprehensive metadata (data about data) is required. Metadata helps define the source and context, as well as any licence terms. 

If the data you receive does not have a clear description of the above mentioned, you should ask the person who is responsible for this dataset to give you specifications. This will allow you to assess if the dataset is right for you.

title: Data requirements
body:
From managing the company to running and delivering projects, data can play a key role in informing us on the best decisions to make.

To get the most from data it is necessary to assess if data can help us solve the problem. This starts with evaluating our rights and legal obligations associated with the data in question.

Following this, we need to set requirements that ensure the data is fit for purpose. This starts with understanding the fundamental terminology and key concepts related to data.

This module looks at the important characteristics of data and how these shape the requirements for using data in projects.

title: Summary
body: The figure here summarises all the key components for data requirements we covered so far.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Establishing the fitness for purpose of a dataset
displayTitle: Establishing the fitness for purpose of a dataset
body:
Fitness for purpose describes how suitable a dataset is to answer a particular question or deliver a particular insight, likely defined in a project scope.

Fitness for purpose may be captured in a set of data requirements, covering topics such as:

_items.title: Rights
_items.body:
Do we have the rights to use the data?

Is the data closed, shared or open? 

Can the data be shared with third parties who need it?

_items.title: Completeness
_items.body:
Do we have the data required for the project?

Are there any missing records, values or timeframes?

_items.title: Conformity
_items.body:
Is there consistency in the data?

Is there a standard that ensures the quality of the data?

Does the data conform to a schema?

Is the data in a suitable format?

_items.title: Accuracy
_items.body:
Are the values of any given record correct and representative of the real-world object in consideration.

Is there any bias in the data?

Has the data been collected correctly?

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: How knowledge is derived from data
body:
Data can be quantitative (i.e. numerical values) or qualitative (i.e. descriptive).

  • “Rainfall yesterday: 5mm” is an example of quantitative data.
  • “Today will be cloudy with sunny periods” is an example of qualitative data.

Data can be:

  • Digital (i.e. stored on or usable by some digital system)
  • Non-digital (e.g. written in a paper notebook)

title: Summary
body:
Data is the fundamental building block from which knowledge is derived. To get the most from data it is necessary to understand the different forms it can take and its application throughout the complete data life cycle. 

At ARUP, we transform complex data into valuable insight to enable our clients to maximise performance and fulfil strategic vision. 

Organisations are now faced with an unprecedented volume and variety. It is essential to understand the key characteristics of this data in order to understand how analytics can be applied and insight delivered.

title: Data usage rights
body:
Not all data can be accessed, used and shared by anyone. Data exists on a spectrum, from closed data like employee records that has limited access, to open data from transport companies that anyone can access, use and share. There is also a large body of shared data that exists between the two, some more closed, some more open. 

Before we agree to deliver a project, we have to consider where data sits on this spectrum and what obligations and legal responsibilities that places on us. 

Explore the spectrum for some examples you might encounter:

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Test your knowledge
instruction: Can you work out the structure of the following?

title: Size
body:
Size refers to the space the data occupies in some kind of storage system, e.g. a hard drive. The size will influence the design of the system required to store, process and share data.

It is important to understand how the size of a dataset may change over time. For example, a dataset generated continuously by sensors will keep growing in size. The growth rate might also fluctuate and not stay constant (i.e. a live feed of public transport status updates may vary considerably depending on conditions on the network).

Predicting growth rates in dataset size requires knowledge of the dataset itself. This should be understood at the requirements phase in order to design and estimate the cost of the adequate system.

title: Test your knowledge
body: Which of the following statements are true?

_items.text: Data in a common schema can be combined with other data with the same schema
Using basic classes of data makes it easier to analyse data
Well structured data is less likely to be biased
All data on the web is open for anyone to access, use and share

title: Schemas
body:
Shown here is an example schema for our dataset. This schema is written in the JSON Schema format and can be used with tools such as csvlint.io to validate a dataset. 

You can download the schema and associated example data and try validating the data against the schema.

_items.text: Referring back to the dataset, why doesn't the dataset conform to this schema?

_options.text: Mismatch in values permitted for "Financial health"
The range for "Years active" is incorrect

title: Defining your requirements
body:
At any point where data is used in a project it is important to carefully define your requirements to ensure the data is fit for purpose.

Fitness for purpose may be captured in a set of data requirements, covering topics such as:

_items.title: Rights
_items.body:
What are our rights regarding this data?

Can the data be shared with third parties?

Can we use this data after we have completed the project?

_items.title: Completeness
_items.body:
Is the data suitable for our analysis?

Are there any missing records, values or timeframes?

Does the data require specific expertise to use it?

_items.title: Conformity
_items.body:
Is the data consistent?

Is there a standard that ensures the quality of the data?

Does the data conform to a schema?

Is the data in a suitable format?

_items.title: Accuracy
_items.body:
Do the values of any given record correctly represent their values?

Has the data been sampled correctly?

Is there any bias in the data?

title: Can you estimate size?
body: See if you can match the data descriptions below to the file sizes.

_items.text: One day of flight schedules for a single airport.

_options.text: 1Mb of data in a single file
20Gb of data in a number of files
20Tb of data in a real time feed

_items.text: Public transport timetables for a country

_options.text: 1Mb of data in a single file
20Gb of data in a number of files
20Tb of data in a real time feed

_items.text: Live locations of all busses in a network (1 year)

_options.text: 1Mb of data in a single file
20Gb of data in a number of files
20Tb of data in a real time feed

title: Structured, semi-structured and unstructured data
body: So far we have been looking at structured data; contained in a format with a tightly controlled vocabulary and schema. This section looks at the three main types of structured, semi-structured and unstructured data.

_items.title: Structured data
_items.body:
Structured data refers to any data stored in a consistent, fixed format. 

Think of data in relational databases or high quality spreadsheets.

Well structured data is often referred to as machine readable; it has a format a computer can process without human assistance. 

Did you know? A sum of "Total" placed at the bottom of a column in a spreadsheet will break machine readability and will disrupt consistent structure. Tip: Place your analysis in a separate sheet!

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

_items.title: Semi-structured data
_items.body:
Semi-structured data does not obey a formal fixed structure. 

Semi-structured data can be:

1. A mix of structured and unstructured data

2. Self-describing using a range of attributes or tags that are not fixed by a single schema.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

_items.title: Unstructured data
_items.body:
Unstructured data is not organised in any pre-defined manner. The majority is text based, such as free text response to a survey.

Typically unstructured data cannot be easily analysed and requires some level of human interpretation, preprocessing or coding.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC0]

title: Relationships matter
body:
Another way to think about the structure of a dataset is in terms of its relationships. These can be between the attributes in a record or between records in a dataset. 

Broadly speaking there are three types of data structure that are suited to each different type of relationship in data: tabular, hierarchical and network.

_items.title: Tabular data
_items.body:
The most common structure for data is tabular. Data is organised into rows, each containing a single record. 

Formats like XLS, CSV and databases like Postgres, MySQL and Oracle are ideally suited for tabular data.

_graphic.attribution: Benjaminec [Shutterstock standard licence]

_items.title: Hierarchical data
_items.body:
Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data records, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country.

Formats such as XML and JSON and semi-structured databases (e.g. NoSQL) are more suited for hierarchical data.

In some cases hierarchical data structures can also be use to embed nested data in a record, e.g.

Company name: ARUP
Company location: {
    lat: 51.5216039
    long: -0.1377894
}

Nested data can also be created using multiple tables in a relational database.

_graphic.attribution: Ing Andrej Kaprinay [Shutterstock standard licence]

_items.title: Network data
_items.body:
Network data allows relationships to exist between any combination of records in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure is a social network. Consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn or your network of friends on Facebook.

Network data can be represented in JSON-LD and XML/RDF. Both of these formats follow the Resource Description Framework (RDF) which simplify and standardise the way network data is represented.

_graphic.attribution: Ovchinnkov Vladimir [Shutterstock standard licence]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
Anna Frajtova [Shutterstock standard licence]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]
